hierarchy.meeting_title: 6953808 - Vividcedar Marketing - buy - Discussion with Ricardo Alvarez

sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Ricardo—good to see you again. Since this is our third call, I’d love to use today to confirm the exact rollout plan and, if everything looks right, get you comfortable moving forward with Customer_Analyzer.
Ricardo Alvarez: Hey Mina. Yes, that’s the goal on my side too. We’ve had good internal traction, I just want to make sure it’ll work with our data reality and that we’re buying the right scope.

Mina Park: Perfect. Let me anchor on what you told me last time: Vividcedar wants to prioritize which industries to target next quarter, and you want that decision grounded in retention and support burden—not just top-of-funnel volume. Still accurate?
Ricardo Alvarez: Exactly. We’ve been chasing a couple verticals because they “look” promising, but our CS team says they’re a drain. We need something more objective than opinions.

Mina Park: That’s exactly where Customer_Analyzer is strongest. I’ll focus on two things today: the Fit Estimation feature—how we compute and explain a fit score—and the segment comparisons that let you stack industries against each other using retention and support signals. Then we’ll talk about data quality and what “good enough” looks like to start.
Ricardo Alvarez: Sounds good. Fit score is the headline for us, but I don’t want a black box number.

Mina Park: Totally. The fit score is 0–100, but the real value is the driver breakdown. You can define fit drivers you care about—like industry, company size, problem severity, time-to-value, adoption patterns, support burden, churn risk signals—and we’ll show exactly which drivers pushed a segment up or down.
Ricardo Alvarez: So if we say “support burden” matters a lot, it’ll weight that?

Mina Park: Yes. You can set weights, or start from our recommended defaults and tune. For your use case—prioritizing industries next quarter—we typically set a heavier weight on retention and support burden, with a secondary weight on time-to-value and expansion. That way you’re not just picking “who converts,” you’re picking “who sticks and grows without crushing your team.”
Ricardo Alvarez: That’s the dream. Right now we’re getting a mismatch between sales and CS incentives.

Mina Park: Exactly—and the segment comparisons help align that conversation. You can compare, say, “Agency Marketing” vs “SaaS Marketing” vs “E-commerce” and see: average fit score, retention outcomes, support tickets per account, and the main drivers. Then the system recommends an ICP profile based on observed outcomes—like the attributes of accounts that convert and renew.

Ricardo Alvarez: Okay, but here’s my concern: our CRM isn’t pristine. We’ve got incomplete fields, inconsistent tagging, and product usage data is decent but not perfect. How sensitive is your scoring to missing data?

Mina Park: Good question—and I want to be direct: data quality does affect scoring accuracy. But you don’t need perfect data to get value. We handle this in three ways. First, we ingest multiple signal sources so you’re not relying on one messy system—CRM plus support tickets plus product usage events, for example. Second, we show data coverage per driver so you can see where you’re making decisions with high confidence versus “needs cleanup.” Third, we can start with a minimal driver set that you have reliably today, and expand over time.
Ricardo Alvarez: What’s “minimal” in your mind for us?

Mina Park: For Vividcedar, based on what you shared: (1) industry and size from CRM—even if imperfect, we can normalize and map common variants; (2) retention outcome—renewed, churned, expanded—however you track it; and (3) support burden from your ticketing system—ticket volume and tags. If we have those three, you can already rank industries for next quarter with more rigor than you have today.
Ricardo Alvarez: We can do that. Our retention outcome is reliable, support tickets are solid, industry is messy but workable.

Mina Park: Great—that’s a very normal starting point. And to avoid the “garbage in, garbage out” worry, we’ll set up the initial model with conservative assumptions. If a segment has low data coverage, the system flags it, and the score reflects uncertainty rather than pretending it’s precise.
Ricardo Alvarez: That’s important. My leadership team will ask, “How do we trust this?”

Mina Park: And the answer is: you trust it because it’s explainable. When your VP asks “Why is e-commerce lower fit than SaaS?”, you can point to the driver breakdown: maybe higher support burden and lower retention outweigh slightly better conversion. It becomes a business discussion, not a debate about anecdotes.
Ricardo Alvarez: Makes sense. Now, in terms of actually using it—how does the output show up for my team?

Mina Park: Two core outputs. First, the fit score at the account and segment level—so your team can look at industries, sizes, even subsegments if you want. Second, positioning recommendations that translate the insights into messaging: value propositions, differentiators, proof points, and objection handling. For today, since we’re trying to get your Q2 industry priority locked, the fit estimation and segment comparisons are the main drivers. Then we can use the positioning piece to arm sales and marketing with a narrative for the chosen industries.
Ricardo Alvarez: I like that you’re not trying to boil the ocean. We want to pick two industries and go all in.

Mina Park: Exactly. That’s the “close the loop” motion: prioritize, then message. One practical example: if a segment scores high because time-to-value is short and support burden is low, we’ll recommend messaging that leans into fast onboarding and low operational overhead—with proof points pulled from your best-fit customers.
Ricardo Alvarez: Okay. Let’s talk implementation. What would the first 30 days look like?

Mina Park: Week 1: connect data sources—CRM, support ticketing, and product usage if you want it now or later. Week 2: define your initial fit drivers and weights—especially retention and support burden for your use case—and run a first scoring pass. Week 3: review segment comparison results with you and one stakeholder from sales/CS to sanity check. Week 4: lock the “recommended ICP profile” and export it into your planning docs, plus the initial positioning recommendations for the top two industries.
Ricardo Alvarez: And what’s the lift on our side?

Mina Park: One ops person for the integrations and field mapping—usually a few hours spread over a week—and then you plus maybe one CS lead for the review session. Most customers like you don’t do a big data cleanup upfront; they start, see gaps highlighted, and then fix the top 3–5 fields that make the biggest difference.
Ricardo Alvarez: That’s realistic. Pricing-wise, we’re aligned with what you sent, but my CFO will ask if we can start smaller.

Mina Park: We can. Given your stated goal—industry prioritization next quarter—the essential scope is Fit Estimation plus segment comparisons, connected to CRM and support tickets. We can start there, and add more data sources or deeper positioning workflows after you’ve proven impact. If you’re ready to move forward today, I can send an order form with that scope and a 12-month term, and we can aim to kick off next Tuesday.
Ricardo Alvarez: Before I say yes, I want to confirm: we can still add product usage later without redoing everything?

Mina Park: Yes. The scoring framework is modular. Adding usage events later just gives you richer drivers—like adoption patterns and time-to-value with more precision. It won’t invalidate what you’ve already learned from retention and support burden; it typically strengthens it.
Ricardo Alvarez: Good. And the messy industry tagging—do you help normalize that, or is that on us?

Mina Park: We help. We’ll provide a mapping layer where “Ecomm,” “E-commerce,” “Online Retail,” etc. can be rolled up consistently. If you want to clean your CRM long term, great, but you don’t need to do that before you get value.
Ricardo Alvarez: Alright. I think we’re there. I can get approval if the contract reflects the lean scope you described and we have a clear success plan.

Mina Park: Great. Let’s define success in plain terms: by end of month one, you have ranked industries using retention plus support burden, you’ve selected your top two target industries for next quarter, and you have an ICP profile you can share with sales and marketing. If we hit that, you’ll have justified the investment quickly.
Ricardo Alvarez: Yes—those are the exact deliverables I want.

Mina Park: Perfect. Next step: I’ll send the order form today with the scope—Fit Estimation, segment comparisons, CRM + support integration—plus an implementation plan and the success criteria we just stated. If you can countersign by Friday, we’ll schedule kickoff for Tuesday.
Ricardo Alvarez: Send it over. I’ll route it to finance this afternoon. Assuming no surprises, we’ll sign by Friday.
Mina Park: Awesome. I’ll get it in your inbox within the hour. Anything else you want to see in the paperwork—security, data retention, or an SLA note?
Ricardo Alvarez: Add the standard security doc and data retention language. That’s usually the last hurdle.
Mina Park: Will do. Thanks, Ricardo—excited to get Vividcedar to a more confident ICP decision for next quarter.
Ricardo Alvarez: Same here. Talk soon once I’ve reviewed the order form.
